author: bmanikm
body:
**What is the issue?**
$PSVersionTable.PSEdition currently supports Desktop and Core enums. Because PowerShell is going to be Open and also available on Linux/Mac from August, we decided to rename these values so as to make it clear to the end user.
We decided to use the names WindowsPowerShell,PowerShellCore.

**How was the issue/bug found?**
Internal brainstorming w.r.t PowerShell efforts.

**What is the user/product impact?**
Long term using the words like "Desktop" confuses customers. We would like customers to be aware of 2 kinds of PowerShell -WindowsPowerShell and PowerShellCore. The word "Desktop" does not align with our long term direction.

comments.author: alexandair
comments.body:
As I'm working with documentation team, I would be grateful if someone can share the info about current branding with me. Is this correct:
"Windows PowerShell" will continue to be used for a version built on full .NET  Framework.
"PowerShell" will be used for open source version, the one built on CoreCLR.

What's the name of the current version on Nano Server?
What name will be used for open source version when it's installed on Windows?
Should we remove all traces of "Open PowerShell", "OpenPowerShell", and OPS from the code and documentation?

comments.author: bmanikm
comments.body:
@alexandair This change is related to $PSVersionTable.PSEdition. As mentioned in the above issue description, PSEdition names will also be renamed in GA release of Windows Server 2016. 

Your below understanding is correct:
         "Windows PowerShell" will continue to be used for a version built on full .NET Framework.
         "PowerShell" will be used for open source version, the one built on CoreCLR.

You are right, we should remove the traces of "Open PowerShell", "OpenPowerShell", and OPS.

On Nano Server, the current value of $PSVersionTable.PSEdition is "Core". In GA release it will be "PowerShellCore".

title: Rename Desktop & Core PSEdition values to WindowsPowerShell & PowerShellCore
